choices: Get up and answer the door.
Turn over and go back to sleep.
1.content:
The loud ring of the doorbell cuts through the silence of the morning, beckoning you out of bed. Of course, you could always ignore it. You could roll back over and hide yourself away under the sheets. It’s not as though you were expecting anyone. Besides, if anyone were to ask why you didn’t answer, well, you were sleeping.

Then again, it could be something terribly important. Maybe it’s an officer here to inform you that one of your family members has been injured in an accident. Perhaps your mother veered into oncoming traffic and had to be rushed to the hospital.

As your mind twists and turns, forming an endless stream of possibilities, the doorbell calls out once more.

“Alright,” you mumble, shifting under your covers. “I’ve gotta make a choice here.”
1.title: Humble beginnings.

choices: A mechanical device shaped like a remote control.
A generic necklace with strange markings etched into it.
A small vial of pale green liquid.
A cylindrical container full of white powder.
11.content:
You stumble out of bed, quickly stretching before you make your way down the stairs. The house is unusually quiet for a Saturday morning. “Everyone must be gone,” you remark to yourself. Usually you’d hear the sound of your sister playing loud pop music, or your mother watching one of her aerobics videos.

When you open the front door you see a small brown package sitting on the porch. “Great,” you say, “I got out of bed for a box.” Turning it over, you notice that it’s addressed to you. “No return address... Definitely wasn’t expecting anything.”

On the way back to your room, you turn the package over a few more times in your hands, inspecting it to make sure it’s not some sort of bomb. Curiosity slowly builds as you try to imagine what it is, or who it’s from. There are no hints on the box itself, no markings other than the ones from postage. It couldn’t hurt to just open it, right? I mean, what are the odds that someone actually wants to bomb you?

Back in your room, you set the box down on your desk and warily remove the packing tape from the top. As you peer inside you find...
11.title: Get up and answer the door.

choices: Ask your mom to look over the device.
Test the device out on your television.
111.content:
Sitting at the bottom of the box is a small device that looks like some kind of remote control. You pick it up and examine it, saying, “What? Is the cable guy sending me stuff now?” There are rows of unmarked buttons and a dial with several strange symbols at every interval. To be honest, it looks pretty common, besides the fact that you have no idea what it’s for.

You turn the dial over and over, trying to make sense of the symbols. There are four that look like a circle with three curved lines above, below, and to each side of it. Another one looks like an oddly shaped “L” with a plus beside it. Opposite that one is another oddly shaped “L” with a minus beside it. There are a few others, but they’re so bizarre that it’s hard to describe them.

From downstairs you can hear the front door open and close, followed by the muffled sound of two women arguing. It’s your mother and your sister, probably back from the store, or wherever they’d run off to. Your sister, Ashley, is probably throwing a fit over not getting her way. It’s nothing new.

The thought of asking your mom to look at the device pops into your head. Then again, she can get paranoid over things like strange packages, or strange remote controls. Maybe you could try it out on the television, see if it turns anything on.
111.title: A mechanical device shaped like a remote control.

1112.content:
You point the remote at the television screen, and with the dial set to the circle with the lines below it, you begin pressing buttons. Nothing happens as you press the smaller buttons near the top, but as soon as you hit a big black button right under the dial, a flash of light blinds you. Your hand quickly covers your eyes, massaging the eyelids in an attempt to help them readjust.

When your sight returns, you can only stare dumbfounded at the television. Instead of your 36 inch plasma screen, there now sits a miniature that looks as though it belongs in a doll house. You can’t believe it. Thoughts whirl inside your head, unable to form an explanation for this.

Magic? Witchcraft? Science fiction?

Whatever the case, it really happened. You turn the dial to the circle with the lines above it, point the remote at the screen once more and hit the button. This time there is no flash of light, and you watch as the television slowly expands. The longer you hold the button, the bigger it gets, until it reaches half of its original size. Your mouth drops open in awe.

This remote has the power to change size. Is it just the T.V.? You turn it toward your desk, press the button, and watch as it slowly expands.

Suddenly you begin to wonder whether or not it would work on humans. If so, the possibilities would be endless. You’re suddenly compelled to use the device on someone. Anyone. Who do you want to use it on, though?
1112.title: Test the device out on your television.

11122.content:
Thoughts racing inside your mind, you decide to use the device on someone else. It would be dangerous to try it on yourself, and besides, it’d be a lot less interesting. You could always go downstairs and test the device on your mother. She’d be completely unaware. Then again, your sister is probably in one of her “bratty” moods. You could always go and toy with her.

What will you do?
11122.title: Use it on someone else.
